threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

last_replies.com:
Okay why do artifacts need low qi capacity?

How about making ones with gigantic qi capacity that just keeps on going without needing to recharge?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1274214
in a fight, qi is used for two things: defending against damage and refilling artifacts. defending against damage benefits from barrier power and it's not hard to get 4+ barrier power, meaning one point of qi sponges four damage. artifacts don't benefit from barrier power, one point of damage is always one qi. there's a multiplier on artifact qi replenishment that i don't remember the name of off the top of my head but it's much rarer than barrier power. SSS gets one skill that increases it by 0.5, t12 sacredsword talisman adds like 1.4, that's about it. so qi damage done to your artifact will proportionally drink much more of your "life bar" than qi damage done to your cultivator does.

artifact qi pools can't be overkilled. if an artifact has 300 max qi because you've been correctly avoiding max qi like the plague and that artifact takes ten million damage, it loses 300 qi, falls to the ground, and drinks 300 of the cultivator's qi reduced by whatever their qi replenishment multiplier is. by always having less max artifact qi than the damage it would have taken, you effectively reduce the amount of qi you're losing through your artifact.

pumping artifact max qi so high that it won't run out during a fight is allegedly a strat for the late game but i've never done it. seems like a gamble that you can lose pretty badly if you calculate wrong.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1274214

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
is a grand STRATEGY GAME that I have been developing, it's not "off-topic", even if it isn't complete.
Set in pseudo-Europe and inspired by Imperator, it seeks not to be another map painter but an empire manager, with a focus on:
>resource management (you need wood to build ships, grain to feed pops, wool to prevent them from freezing, etc)
>pop management (who all have their wealth)
>character management
>closed economy with prepaid-model
>anti-omniscience (limited information, e.g. you don't know many troops other countries have)
>faction management (all characters belong to a faction, and everything you do impact the faction's loyalty, if you go to war against the faction's beloved country, they might revolt against you)
>army management (army depletes as you advance because you have to leave troops behind to garrison)
>making the world evolve (you turn forests into farmlands, build bridges over rivers, convert villages to cities)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1264462
Vicky 2 has a lot of problems and really is not that fun of a game in single player, anon. Vicky 2 is summed up by "great concept, terrible execution" and that mantra holds true for basically every aspect of the game - from the Scramble for Africa to the Crisis system.
Most PDX games, the gimmick is that you start small and gradually build up. In CK2, players are told that characters above emperor are "pointless" to play, for example. But with Vicky, the game isn't worth playing unless you are one of the ~12 powers who is a GP or can easily become one (Japan, China, Mexico, CSA, Netherlands, Spain, etc.). Nations that are less powerful than that simply have so little control that you are at the mercy of AI superpowers. The game isn't long enough for a small nation like, say, Afghanistan to work its way up to the global superpower.
The main appeal of Vicky 2 is that it's a "simulator" for the 19th century. You're playing an alternate history, that sort of thing. However, the AI isn't good enough to do anything interesting most times. In reality, the Victorian era had many. many close calls where different powers nearly got colonies in weird places (Russia tried to colonize Hawaii, Belgium tried to colonize Texas after it beat Mexico, Russia tried to colonize Djibouti, etc.). You will never see Russian Hawaii even though it's actually historically plausible.
The game is overly rigid due to the limitations of the events/decision system for railroading. Like, powers regularly sold territory to one another at the time, but there is no system for dynamic sales. Instead, it's a handful of railroaded ones that occurred historically, like the Alaskan Purchase.
Great concept, terrible execution.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1272227
If a neighbor claims a system before you do, your game is basically running on 1/3 speed as you gotta hack 3 times to get a sanctuary.
If a neighbor claims a chokepoint or even consecutive systems, you gotta go the long way so they don't run a trace. If a capital has no special nodes or unclaimed system around it you take a big gamble to hack.

These are all midgame constraints, but you can't even go wild early game because you tech colonization normally, so systems you can hack has a high chance of also being available to neighbors. Also the punishing happiness penalties.
Lategame, invading is the best route to gain sanctuaries anyway. Personally, I find the best way to win as UC is to spam "rebellion" hack on enemy capitals until they collapse.

UC is the best at not losing, but for winning they are pretty average, like the capital-less Vaulters.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1273136
You're usually given plenty of room to expand before finding another empire, and overcolonization often isn't a real problem since the only system you have to manage the happiness of is the capital's. If an enemy expands into a system you control you can just sleeper the hell out of them.
You also have a head-start on cloaking technology and can get to higher levels far sooner than anyone else, which means you can have a whole invasion fleet wandering the galaxy traveling at high speeds due to the amount of movement bonuses that are usually available (innate faction bonus to ship movement, early science faction policy, seeker hero given by quests etc), which also makes it extremely good for domination victories since your fleet can just pop into an enemy capital, invade it, purge it, convert all the colonized planets into sanctuaries which counts for the "have enough enemy capital systems under your control" victory condition and then re-stealth afterwards while the enemy can't really do shit other than have anti-cloaking technology. It's only until lategame that they can finally start having trouble as more empires research level 3 anti-cloaking but by then it's far too late because the UC, virtually uncontested, has already snowballed out of control. I've played both vs AI and vs players with them, with the former I managed to do a relatively easy victory on the hardest difficulty without even fighting, while against the latter they were always weaker than the UC.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1273375
No no, if they colonize a system you have sanctuaries on you can sacrifice UC population there to turn their pops into sleepers. Sleeper reintegration is very slow, slaps the system with a happiness penalty, doesn't actually reveal if the system has any sleepers on it in the first place until it's done, and if their entire system has sleepers when they run Sleeper Cull they will literally end up with no population there. It's an important thing to note that thanks to the hyper-tall gameplay of the UC they have monstrous food production to the point it's trivial to generate a bunch of pops at a time, and they can redirect the food growth to specific sanctuary systems as a result.
>what does sleepers even do anyway
Provides information on a system IIRC, enough of them can leech several resource incomes such as dust and strategic ones on an empire-wide scale even if they're all localized on a system (funny enough the leeching is visible to the empire that gets leeched if they hover over their own resources but it's attributed to a bunch of bogus reasons). If the UC invades a system they can reclaim all the sleepers there to turn into "umbral shadows" on their home world who are better UC pops. I think a bunch of quest rewards give you laws that give you bonuses for each sleeper and other laws that give you bonuses for umbral shadows.
>You want 3 planets and up only
Anon....... the overcolonization limit is based on systems, not planets. And since you only have to manage the homeworld's happiness it's somewhat trivial to maintain, especially if you dip into the government quadrant. And the first UC hero is a governor that can give +5 happiness per sanctuary (not system, sanctuary) which can nearly negate overcolonization penalties. Early on you want to spread as far wide as possible and then slow down a bit during mid-game because a system's stealth level is dependent on how many planets are sanctuaries (max 3).
(1/2)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1273379
(2/2)
>How? PvP as UC gets me dogpiled quick and it's relatively easy to guess where their system is.
They try to dogpile you because UC is OP as fuck and they know that if they don't focus on you you're gonna stomp everyone.
Anyway:
>fleet
I recall there is a mechanic that allows cloaked ships to start closer to the enemy during the combat phase, which means it's way easier for them to get within kinetic slug range and shred the enemy in close range. Building a fleet is trivial because of your system's monstrous industrial output as a result of its interaction with sanctuaries, but the bigger problem is manpower, and you can't do much about that other than I think use the thing that consumes a pop to make manpower.
>economy
You might want to rush the techs that give you bonus outputs for each sanctuary, early on that's the xenoforge (or whatever, but industry is very important in the game) and the blue science thing, afterwards it's that logistics improvement that gives you a flat industry bonus for each sanctuary, but don't spread out TOO much or your happiness will be low. Behemoths are cloaked too unless they're specialized. You'll naturally end up generating plenty of resources. You also have an advantage when it comes to making wonders but I don't think it's a good idea to make the market wonder because it marks your system on the map for everyone to see.
Your homeworld's stealth level depends on its system improvement level, I think level 4 makes it plain undetectable but I'm not sure.
>hacking
It's your bread and butter, use it for expanding at first and foremost because expanding is good. Hack systems within reach, then re-hack those systems to make more sanctuaries. You have no shortage of bandwidth, use a bunch for special feature beacons to teleport your homeworld to in case of emergency (and it gives the feature's bonus while it's active). People have to cripple their bandwidth on defensive programs on their systems to stop your hacking.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Hexes are cleaner, more intuitive, and less ambiguous. They're easier to create rulesets for. The only problem is that human constructs rely heavily on right angles, so a battlefield on the scale of individuals in an artificial environment goes right to shit when you try and use hexes.

>i read that the 2.0 actually made game worse
There’s exactly 1 anon saying that, and his entire argument boils down to “ai can’t use the new mechanics,” as if this is new to literally any paradox game, let alone a strategy vidya. You can safely ignore him.

>every country besides Rome feels the same and repetitive
This has been true since launch, and is still true. Rome’s issue also is that it’s not different enough. Your best bet for more flavor is Invictus, and even that has its own issues but if you like the gameplay you can still get a few campaigns out of it. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1261865
It depends what kind of strategy game that you want to get into
>i want bigass battles
Total War Shogun and Medieval are good starts then. Shogun is very simple and to the point, Medieval is also simple but you have more faction variety. Both are $10 on Steam and have GoG versions irrc
>i want starcraft but easy
Dawn of War is a great tittle for you. The base game's campaign is one big tutorial that teaches you just about everything there is to know
>i want to paint maps and feel smart
Europa Universalis 3 is the game for you then. While 4 is certainly easier, the UI is such a mess that most new players drop it. EU3 is simple enough to pick up easily, while still keeping plenty of depth
>i want turn based shit
Field of Glory 2 is an easy one to pick up, most of it is rng, and you can always give yourself a much bigger army if you cant beat the ai. Not too many major mechanics to worry about either
>i wanna build cities without getting autistic
Civilization Revolution is a great 4x game to play then. It covers all the fundamentals and it's far faster than any mainline Civ game. A toaster oven could emulate the DS version of the game, and the 360 version which has better graphics is emulateable if you have a decent pc
>i want to build cities autistically
You can get Sim City 2000 for free at this point, it's got everything you need. It also has one of the better tutorials for the genre
>i want some jap shit
Depends on which you want
>turn based jap shit
Fire Emblem, Advanced Wars, and Pokemon Conquest are all easy strategy games to pick up, each one has just enough depth to warrant 2nd playthroughs too. All can easily be emulated
